displayed_text: Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo. Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I had the blood test done this morning. Is that what we were reading off for the PSA this morning? Doctor: Yep. Yeah. You might give me a little bit longer than two weeks since you don’t go to Medicare, huh, until, huh, Friday. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yeah. March first it kicks in. I’ve got the card on me if you need it. Family Member: I’ve also got that, our insurance too. Doctor: Okay. So I just emailed the pharmacist to let them know what we’re thinking, huh, to get you started, that’s you’ve switched to Medicare, and that they might end up looking next week. Huh, so hopefully, in the next week or two we’ll know where you are. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, and then, huh, they’ll usually reach out to you about that results. And then, huh, huh, and then I have an appointment if you check out that will coincide with your next shot. Patient: Right. Doctor: Blood work a few days in advance at B___ and a visit with me. So likely that you’re going to be on the abiraterone as you come into that visit. Huh, it’s just an issue of us getting it started. So if you haven’t heard in the next ten days let me know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, because of the Medicare switch, that may be sort of the only delay.

Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something. Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was.

Patient: In your, do you know what’s happening, I’m sure you do. Doctor: Yes. Patient: What’s happening now that I need more, sorry I don’t know why this happened but… Doctor: You got excited. Patient: Yeah (Laughing and all speaking at once.) Family Member: Take two. Patient: I’m just different, it happens here. Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Until we can go and talk about that. No rush. Plus your next shot I think is April fourth. So we may uh, you know, we’ll work on that, but you may even be, you come in at the same time, and we can use that same visit. So I’ll look at that. Okay? Any questions? Patient: I didn’t know that you - So that’s what I had? I had cancer, I mean, uh, I had pneumonia and-? Doctor: Pneumonia and the flu. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: The flu? Yeah. That’s what I had before. Doctor: Yeah. I think that’s what happened when I talked to your doctor. They were for sure about pneumonia. They were waiting on the flu results at the time. But I think they treated you like you had the flu, anyway, so. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: By the time there the next day they gave me some potassium and they gave me antibiotics. Doctor: Um hum. Um hum. Yeah. Patient: And was walking in an hour or two. Doctor: Yeah. And you were really dehydrated. Patient: Yeah I was.

Patient: Yeah I was. Doctor: So they had to give you a lot of fluids. So your doctor’s pretty, pretty worried. Your, your lungs, you know, they’re already not great with the cancer but then you had pneumonia on top of that, so. Well, we’ll get those records to make sure that’s, and you know, kind of what ended up happening because they couldn’t give me anything until you were discharged. So now that you’re discharged for a couple of days, they’ll send that up, up to us. Patient: Yeah, Uh the last time they gave me something to take home, antibiotics, some kind of antibiotics to take home, that just I didn’t get nothing. Doctor: Okay. You didn’t get some this time? Okay. So it might have been more flu. Yeah. Okay. So, I’ll, I’ll have M___ come in and say hello and then we’ll have you come back here in a couple of weeks and let’s, let’s run through it. Awesome. Glad you’re back. You scared me. Doctor: You take care of him. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I’ll have her come in and we’ll, we’ll get you out of here. Alright. I’ll see you guys. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and… Doctor: Well again I’m just getting more data as we’re talking here. Patient: I also sent saliva to do DNA test – Doctor: Uh huh. Patient: - and the thing has said it’s not hereditary. Family Member: That’s the copy. Doctor: Okay, I’ll take a look at it Patient: When I was in the hospital checking every day - Doctor: Today your creatinine is one point zero. And your liver tests are all normal. Your PSA is pending; it looks like – Patient: They didn’t know. Doctor: It just hasn’t resulted yet. Family Member: Uh, the last reading when we were here on the twelfth of November, the reading was seventeen for PSA. Did that corrected? Doctor: Seventeen.

Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. Doctor: You know kind of maybe just don't want to hang there. You know, they're not sick all the time. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we… Doctor: Exactly. Patient: We got to find out. Doctor: So, you guys now are on the same page as me in terms of what to expect after the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I never order stuff when it’s, I don’t want it to be a mystery. You guys should know exactly what we’re going to do depending on the results. Patient: Okay. I like that.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But I haven’t, I don’t cure anybody with prostate cancer, so I’m getting frustrated in my career. You know? Is there something I can do that has a chance to cure the disease? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The only thing I could think of, so we’re testing the bone marrow transplant idea is being prostate. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So their immune system has not been exposed to prostate tissue. What if we used a female into a male? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The other things we’re looking at is keeping the male castrated so all the prostate genes are turned off, and then after the new bone marrow gets all happy, you get a couple of pulse of testosterone, not to treat the cancer but to turn on the genes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To get the immune system. This new immune system, saying what the hell is that? It’s almost like an infection. So we’re in the early stages. We’ve treated two men. I can’t say much other than you know they did pretty well with the transplant part. Uh we’re following them. It’s really designed, my idea is for younger men, you know, less than seventy, and that is younger for me, uh, where, you know, unfortunately, you know prostate cancer grows slowly in most men. You’re probably going to live long enough that this is you know could be really- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, we’re, we’re uh cautiously optimistic. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And also… Family Member: And does he do it here in the office with you guys? Doctor: So typically it’s an injection. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s also a yearlong implant that you can do. I wouldn’t do it for your first injection, Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but um the injection is just liquid medication that gets injected and it forces your testosterone level to go down. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The testicles produce testosterone as a normal function. PAT Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have less testosterone in your body and so that helps get rid or any or suppress or get rid of any cancer cells that are remaining. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: I enjoyed participating in this study! It was interesting to put myself in the shoes of the patient for each scenario.

displayed_text: Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step.

Healthcare Professional: You didn’t tell me your were throwing up, you told me you was just having diarrhea. Patient: No I told you I throwed up three times. Doctor: When was the last time? Patient: Same time I was having diarrhea. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I threw up times. I have Doctor: I think we should refer him to GI because I really don’t know what uh… Patient: What? Doctor: I have no idea. I’ve never seen that. Patient: Yeah me either. Doctor: And we can’t see it on the CAT scan either. So I don’t know what to make of it. Patient: What?

Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t combine Zytiga and the radium together. I specifically say that because there have been patients who have had leftover pills and yeah. Hey, the things going up after I try the pill. But actually, when they combined it people did worse so that study has already been done and people got more bone fractures so that’s no fun. So, I just tell everybody, you know, you’ve had it before. You can go on it after but not at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s actually an absolute no-go black box. Okay, good. Family Member: What does the PSA going up, what does it, is it gonna cause it to spread? Doctor: It might really. No. But it might, again it’s not a reflection of what’s happening. It’s almost like oh, the ship’s sinking and the rats are all kind of jumping off. I’ve had patients that go from twenty to one hundred to five hundred and you’re like, oh, but they actually feel better. So, like it doesn’t match you.
